item.title: How do i code ::dp1-::dp8 :S (317)
item.dc:creator: @Canownueazy Canownueazy
item.description:
@Canownueazy wrote:

[quote=“Tatemo, post:11, topic:364849”]Oh yeah. Because that is going to work with his server.

Your code is extremely server specific, e.g requiring a location class.

Mine is dynamic except for the spawn item bit.

Also I was posting two separate pieces of code. The array was to go somewhere else.

Yours may be better code but it is hardly appropriate.

Also just to be as equal a cunt as you. You never declared a dropParty1 array.[/quote]Mine isn’t “server specific” it’s specific to Hyperion.

And if you don’t have a dang Location class.

public class Location { public Location(int x, int y) { this.x = x; this.y = y; } public static Location create(int x, int y) { return new Location(x, y); } private int x, y; public int getX() { return x; } public int getY() { return y; } }

Read full topic

item.title: How do i code ::dp1-::dp8 :S (317)
item.dc:creator: @Canownueazy Canownueazy
item.description:
@Canownueazy wrote:

[quote=“Tatemo, post:8, topic:364849”]Oh god. What happened to good code seriously.

Why are you not using an array! WHAT ARE YOU DOING!!!
YOU MONSTERS!!!

Seriously.

[code=java]public int dropParty1[] = {PUT ITEM IDS IN HERE};
make more ints for other drop parties!

if(command.equalsIgnoreCase(“dp”)&& playerRights >= 3){
for(int i = 0; i < dropParty1.length; i++) {
ItemHandler.addItem(dropParty1[i], absX+Misc.random(3), absY+Misc.random(3), playerItemsN[1], playerId, false);

}
}[/code][/quote]Pretty sure he doesn’t want items spawning on the same location.

Also the fuck with not just looping through the array? And a public array? Are we going to be accessing it from other classes or something? And I’m pretty sure you can’t declare public fields (variables ect…) in a method (most likely the command handling is done in a method and command should be implementing a ‘Packet’)

ArrayList<Location> taken = new ArrayList<Location>;

We could hold our locations in an array list.

Random r = new Random();

A random for spreading out the items.

for(int id : dropParty1) { int dis = Math.sqrt((int)dropParty1.size()); Location loc = Location.create(player.getLocation().getX() + r.nextInt(dis), player.getLocation().getY() + r.nextInt(dis)); if(!taken.contains(loc)) { taken.add(loc); World.getWorld().register(new GroundItem(id, World.getWorld().getPlayers(), loc)); } if(taken.size() == dropParty1.size()) { taken.clear(); break; } }

We loop through the ‘dropParty1’ array.

We get the distance (square root of the amount of items in the ‘dropParty1’ array so 9 items = 3 spaces) and convert that to an int (rounds)

Next we create the location that the item will be placed.

We now check if the taken arraylist does not contain the generated loc.

If so, we add the generated loc to the arraylist, and then spawn the ground item.

We then check if the size of the ‘taken’ arraylist is the size of the ‘dropParty1’ array. If so, we stop the loop and clear the taken arraylist (for further usage later?)

Read full topic
